items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.01
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Director, Human Resources
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m.
Disclosure of Major Provisions of Proposed Tentative Agreement with East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA, August 31, 2013 – August 31, 2014 (per AB1200); Discussion and/or Action – Cari Vaeth, Director, Human Resources
	                       
	 
	 
In accordance with Assembly Bill 1200 requiring school districts to disclose, at a public meeting, the cost that would be incurred by the implementation of a collective bargaining agreement.  In meeting the requirement, a public hearing is being held to give our community an opportunity to comment on the cost of this tentative agreement.
	 
Attached is a copy of the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement with the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA.  The District and the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA reached a tentative agreement on October 31, 2013.  The tentative agreement was ratified by the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA on November 13, 2013.
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board accept any comment on the proposed Tentative Agreement with the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA, August 31, 2013 – August 31, 2014.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Ed Tech General Obligation Bond Voter Survey
	 
	 
Technology changes by the day; fundamentally changing how we as a society interact with information and with each other.  We no longer rely on textbooks, newspapers or magazines to gain knowledge from information; it is replaced with streaming news content, Google searches and Wikipedia. We communicate with each other via e-mail, Facebook, Twitter and YouTube, while shopping online and paying bills with online banking and PayPal. For a majority of companies, work is conducted via 24-hour access to the Internet, teleconferencing, Skype and Google Docs.   
	 
Our schools must meet the changing demands of technology and prepare our students for 21st century jobs and careers.  With the adoption of the Common Core Standards, we must change the way we teach, the way students demonstrate their learning and how we assess students with the new Smarter Balanced Assessment system, which will require us to administer all of our State assessments and benchmark assessments online.  Furthermore, in the not so distance future, all textbooks will be offered as eBooks and we need to find a way for each student to access these new textbooks. 
	 
Proposition 39 both permits and encourages the financing of technology.  Ed Tech Bonds amortization matches the technology useful life; matches the life of the loan to the life of the asset.  Ed Tech Bonds provide all components of a successful tech plan, including but not limited to devices, software, infrastructure and installation and training.
	 
The Board is asked to consider the timing for issuance and whether to direct the District to undertake a random telephone survey of voters to determine their support for an Ed Tech GO Bond election.  The cost of conducting the bond survey will be paid from the bond proceeds if the Board approves the action and the election is successful.
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Obligation Bonds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees discuss, consider and direct the District on whether to pursue an Ed Tech GO Bond election, determine optimal time for issuance, and undertake a random telephone survey of voters to determine support.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees discuss, consider and direct the District on whether to pursue an Ed Tech GO Bond election, determine optimal time for issuance, and undertake a random telephone survey of voters to determine support.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading of ESUHSD Strategic Plan
	 
	 
During the Spring of 2013, the Superintendent held a total of 22 community conversations and focus group discussions, soliciting feedback from parents, students, teachers, administrators and community members regarding the District’s performance and its future focus and priorities.  Evening meetings were held at each of the District’s high schools, and focus group discussions were organized in order to solicit feedback from targeted groups of stakeholders.
	 
Meetings were also conducted with the Superintendent’s Cabinet to solicit the development of objectives, goals and strategies for the Strategic Plan, including Study Sessions with the Board.
	 
As part of the Strategic Plan, a Theory of Action was developed, which is based on improving the quality of instruction and the key relationships; the student to the teacher and the school to the home.  
	 
As a result of these meetings, five key performance measures were identified:
	 
1.   Graduation rate
2.   Dropout rate
3.   A-G completion rate 
4.   College & Career Readiness (5Cs)
5.   Eliminate the Achievement Gap
	 
To guide the key performance measures in the strategic planning process, five key objectives were developed:
	 
1.   Quality Learning & Instruction 
2.   Professional Learning Communities/Social Capital
3.   Innovative Learning Structures
4.   Aligned Resources
5.   Stakeholder Engagement
	 
Attached for the Board’s review and first reading is the District’s proposed Strategic Plan, which is a result of the hard work of all stakeholders during the Strategic Plan engagement process.  
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
	Not Applicable
FUNDING SOURCE:
	Not Applicable
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the first reading of the ESUHSD Strategic Plan.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.06
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Frank Biehl, Board President
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Call for Nominations to CSBA Delegate Assembly
	 
	 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for the CSBA Delegate Assembly.  Any CSBA member board is eligible to nominate board members within their geographical region or subregion.  Boards may nominate as many individuals as it chooses by submitting a nomination form for each nominee.  All nominees must give their approval prior to being nominated to CSBA's Delegate Assembly.
	 
All nominees must submit a one-page, single-sided, candidate biographical sketch form and an optional one-page, one-sided resume (resume cannot be substituted for the candidate biographical sketch form).  All nominations must be postmarked no later than Tuesday, January 7, 2014.  Faxes are also acceptable, but must be received by January 7, 2014.
	 
Delegates serve  two-year terms, beginning April 1, 2014, through March 31, 2016.  There are two required Delegate Assembly meetings each year, one in May in Sacramento and one preceding the CSBA Annual Education Conference and Trade Show in November/December.
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Expenses to attend required meetings.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommend that the Board of Trustees submit nomination(s) to the CSBA Delegate Assembly.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Vanessa Vitug, Mt. Pleasant Teacher
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding the Yale National Initiative
	 
Five (5) East Side Union High School District teachers joined 55 public school teachers, from sixteen school districts, in nine (9) states, to complete national seminars and an intensive session as part of the Yale National Initiative to strengthen teaching in public schools. The dual purpose of the national seminars is to provide public school teachers a deeper knowledge of the subjects they teach and first-hand experience with the Teachers Institute approach to high-quality professional development.  This increases their leadership in an existing Teachers Institute or prepares them to lead the development of a new Teachers Institute. Each teacher writes a curriculum unit to teach his or her students about the seminar subject and to share with other teachers in their school district, and over the Internet with teachers anywhere.  The curriculum units implement academic standards of the teachers’ school districts and assist the teachers in engaging and educating their students.  East Side teachers spent two (2) weeks living on the Yale campus and participated in ten (10) two-hour daily seminars and conferred individually with their seminar leaders as they developed the curriculum unit.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.02
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and and/or Action to Approve the Plan to Utilize Common Core State Funds
		 
The State of California is allocating funds to assist districts in the implementation of Common Core State Standards.  The money will come in two installments and districts must have a board approved plan for spending the money.  The funds can only be spent in three areas, technology, instructional materials, and professional development.  The plan must be submitted to the board for review and an accompanying public hearing must be held.  The board can not act on or approve the plan until the next regular board meeting. The Board of Trustees reviewed the plan at the October 17th board meeting. The Board of Trustees must now either approve or deny  the plan. 
		 
		 
As a condition of receiving these funds, the district will have to expend the funds by June 30, 2015.  On or before July 1, 2015, the district will have to report detailed expenditure information to the State Department of Education, including, but not limited to, specific purchases made and the number of teachers, administrators, or paraprofessional educators that received professional development.  The State Department of Education will be determining the format for this report.
		 
Fiscal Impact:
One time Restricted State Funds
		 
Funding Source:
Projected - 4.7 Million
		 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Plan to Utilize Common Core State Funds.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  12.03
			 
			 
			 
TO:
  Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:
  Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Rate of Pay Increase for Campus Police Officers
			 
			 
SUMMARY
Effective July 1, 2009, San Jose Police Department (SJPD) implemented a standard hourly rate for officers for all outside uniform employment (i.e., campus security officers, etc.).  The minimum rate per hour is $46.50 for officers.  Their current rate of pay with East Side is $44.00 per hour for officers, $51.00 per hour for coordinators and $54.00 per hour for the District Coordinator.
			 
In order to comply with San Jose Police Department standards, Administration is requesting that the rate of pay for campus officers be increased to $46.50 per hour for campus safety supervision and $51.00 per hour for extracurricular activities.  Not only would this allow SJPD to continue to provide the District with adequate safety supervision but also allow the District to be competitive with surrounding districts and alleviate the difficulty that the District is experiencing in providing sufficient coverage for extracurricular activities.
			 
Administration is requesting that the hourly rate of pay for the site coordinators and District Security Coordinator remain the same.  Administration is also requesting that the increase to $51.00 per hour for extracurricular activities be retroactive to October 18, 2013, and the rate for regular officers take effect November 1, 2013.
			 
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
$50,000
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund/ASB
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the increases for campus police officers hourly rates of pay to meet the San Jose Police Department’s standards.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  13.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Facility Sub Lease and Related Agreements with Educare of Silicon Valley and Franklin McKinley School District for Early Childhood Education Program Facilities for ESUHSD Programs; Approve Resolution #2013/2014-11  re:  Delegation of Authority to Associate Superintendent to Approve Final Form of Sub Lease and Related Agreements for Early Childhood Education Program Facilities for ESUHSD Programs
	 
	 
	 
At the direction and authorization of the Board, Legal Counsel and Administration have been in negotiations with representatives of Franklin McKinley School District (FMSD) and Educare of California at Silicon Valley, a 501(c)(3) non-profit corporation (ECSV), and related parties for a lease and related agreements for the construction of a portion of the proposed and planned ECSV facility on FMSD property adjacent to the Santee Elementary School site.  The Board previously approved an allocation of $1,000,000 from Measure I funds towards the construction of the facility which will house an early childhood education career academy for ESUHSD students to be administered by ESUHSD staff.  In addition, the ECSV early childhood education facility, when completed, will include, but not be limited to, delivery of preschool and parenting services and programs, which will allow the District the opportunity to transfer such existing programs to the new ECSV facility and allow opportunities for alternative uses of the existing YBHS facilities.
	 
The ECSV facility will be constructed on land owned by FMSD within the ESUHSD jurisdiction.  ESUHSD will be allocated five (5) classrooms (approximately 5,000 square feet) and ancillary space at the facility for the ESUHSD early childhood education career academy.  The current construction budget for the facility is approximately $12,882,000.  In addition to the District’s contribution, the construction will be funded through a contribution of $800,000 in bond funds from FMSD, funding through the federal New Market Tax Credits program (made available to ECSV) and private fundraising and contributions.  The facility design will be DSA-approved and the design and construction will be compliant with the California Education Code and Code of Regulations applicable to public school construction.
	 
The construction of the facility will be administered and overseen by FMSD pursuant to a Development Agreement.  ESUHSD’s contribution will be paid by ESUHSD to FMSD to be applied strictly by FMSD to the construction of the facility, including ESUHSD’s classroom facilities, subject to record-keeping and accounting obligations by FMSD.  Once construction of the facility is complete, the overall facility will be leased by ECSV which will then, in turn, sublease a portion of the facility (5 classrooms and ancillary spaces) to ESUHSD for the District’s early childhood education career academy.  
	 
Negotiation of the Development Agreement, Sublease and other agreements are still underway and will be presented to the Board in the most current draft form at time of, or before, the Board meeting.  Presently, the term of the ESUHSD sublease for the facility is twenty-two (22) years; rent would be nominal (e.g., $1.00 per year).  ECSV would be contractually responsible for all operating and maintenance costs for the facility throughout the sublease term.
	 
Presently, and to take full advantage of available New Markets Tax Credit financing, the transaction group is targeting a transaction closing of early to mid-December 2013.  However, the next Regular Board meeting is December 12, 2013.  Therefore, to allow a pre-December 12 closing the Board would need to delegate the authority to Administration (Associate Superintendent of Business Services) to approve the Sublease and related agreements necessary to consummate this transaction, including but not limited to the Development Agreement, subject to later ratification by the Board.  Education Code section 17604 authorizes the Board, by a majority vote, to delegate to the District Superintendent or to any other persons that he or she may designate, or if there be no District Superintendent, then to any other officer or employee of the District that the Board may designate, authority to enter into contracts that may be limited as to time, money or subject matter or may be a blanket authorization in advance of its exercise, all as the Board may direct; provided, however, that “. . . no contract made pursuant to the delegation and authorization shall be valid or constitute an enforceable obligation against the District unless and until the same shall have been approved or ratified by the Governing Board, the approval or ratification to be evidenced by a motion of the Board duly passed and adopted.”
	 
The Board is requested to delegate such authority to Associate Superintendent of Business Services Marcus Battle to negotiate and execute the final form of Sublease, Development Agreement and necessary related agreements, if any, consistent with the above general contractual parameters and subject to final ratification of such agreements by the Board at a subsequent Board meeting.
	 
Funding Source:
Measure I
	 
Fiscal Impact:
Not to exceed $1,000,000 in Measure I funds; nominal lease payments (if any) to be paid from General Fund
	 
Recommendation:
Administration recommends that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 2013/2014-11 Delegating Authority to the Associate Superintendent of Business Services to Approve Final Form of Sublease, Development Agreement and Related Agreements for Early Childhood Education Program Facilities for ESUHSD Programs.

TO:

FROM:
  Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Julio Lucas, District Architect
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action on Education Center Entry Sign
			 
			 
The proposed sign replacement at 830 North Capitol Avenue is part of a very small streetscape improvement project.  The goal of the project is to improve wayfinding to the Education Center, create a more welcoming entrance experience, and replace gate and signage elements that have reached their useful service life.  
			 
Attachment A provides a preliminary graphical representation of the small amount of landscaping that will bookend either side of the entrance drive at the street.  The existing signage on the south side of the drive will be replaced as well.  Although the new sign depicted on Attachment A appears to be curved, the new sign will be parallel to the street and in the same location, to take advantage of existing lighting. 
			 
There will be minor yet symbolic differences of wording on the new sign.  The existing sign’s primary text indicates “Education Center”, with secondary text indicating “East Side Union High School District”.  The new sign will improve wayfinding by flipping the primary and secondary text.  By emphasizing with primary text the District’s name, the site will be more recognizable to the community at large.  
			 
The secondary text can indicate “Education Center” or “Central Office”.  Graphical examples of both are shown on Attachment B.
			 
			 
Fiscal Impact:
Not applicable
			 
			 
Funding Source:
Not applicable
			 
			 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees provide direction on the secondary text for the new entry sign at 830 North Capitol Avenue.

Item:  15.02
			 
			 
TO:
  Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:
  Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Julio Lucas, District Architect
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion Bond Program Community Gratitude Signage
			 
			 
The existing Bond Measure E Community Gratitude Signage has lived its useful life. The signs have weathered poorly, contain outdated information, and visually detract from the message of gratefulness and renewal that wants to be associated with the bond measures that have enabled the capital construction program. 
			 
The signs will be replaced.  The following criteria/parameters have inspired the preliminary design of the new signage:
The text will reflect all currently active bond measures (G, E, I) and possible future measures as well.  This will allow the signage to bridge funding sources over time, so that the signage text does not age out.
School sites with multi-color large format digital marquees (Andrew Hill, Mount Pleasant, Overfelt Adult Education) will display the community gratitude message using the digital signage, in lieu of placement of physical signs.  The gratitude message will rotate among other site-generated messages.  This cost saving measure will also eliminate vandalism to physical signs at those sites with digital marquees.
The design will enable text in the lower section to be economically refreshed.
The graphic design will convey a sense of place of the East Side Union High School District, and reflect a genuine gratitude for the community’s support and what it means to our students.
The design will withstand the test of time and weather.
			 
Images of the existing signage, the inspiration for the new signage, and a preliminary mockup of the proposed new signage are depicted in the attached presentation.
			 
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
Not applicable
			 
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
			 
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees provide feedback on the proposed replacement bond measure community gratitude signage design.

Item:  15.03
		 
		 
TO:
  Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
  Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Kenneth Kerch, AIA, SGI Bond Program Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action on the Update of the Bond Program
		 
		 
In 2002, voters in the East Side Union High School District approved Bond Measure G in the amount of $298 million for the purpose of modernizing existing school facilities and building new facilities to support the changing needs of K-12 education in the District. A substantial portfolio of projects has been completed under Measure G, which is concluding with a district-wide site improvement initiative, currently underway.
		 
In 2008, voters in the District approved Bond Measure E in the amount of $349 million for the purpose of continuing modernization of existing school facilities and building of new facilities to support the changing needs of K-12 education in the District. To date, 41 Measure E projects have been completed, 10 are in bid/design, and 8 are under construction.
		 
In 2012, voters in the District approved Bond Measure I in the amount of $120 million for the purpose of continuing modernization of existing school facilities and building of new facilities to support the changing needs of K-12 education in the District. Planning is in progress to identify the projects to be completed with Measure I funds.
		 
An update on the status of the District’s bond program is presented for discussion (Attachment A).

Not Applicable

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  20.02
	 
	 
TO:
  Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:
  Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Measure I Distribution for San Jose Conservation Corps and Charter School
	 
	 
Under Proposition 39, San Jose Conservation Corps and Charter School (SJCC) is eligible for the District’s Bond Measure I proceeds.  Bond funds may only be used to improve District buildings and properties and/or to provide appropriate equipment.  On June 27, 2013, the Board of Trustees approved a Measure I Prioritization List that allocated funds to SJCC in the amount of $37,476 (Board item 15.05).
	 
SJCC serves 424 students.  Of those students, 305 reside within East Side Union High School District boundaries.  They have identified a need for 60 iPads to support instruction, students and staff, and would like to use their Measure I funds to remedy this equipment deficiency.  District staff support SJCC's request, to the limit of available Measure I funding, based on providing equivalency of facilities standards for classrooms and typical furniture and equipment provisions for students and staff.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  20.03
			 
			 
TO:
  Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:
  Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Kenneth Kerch, SGI Bond Program Manager
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Measure E Distribution for Latino College Preparatory Academy and Charter School
			 
			 
			 
Under Proposition 39, Latino College Preparatory Academy and Charter School (LCPA) is eligible for the District’s Bond Measure proceeds.  Bond funds may only be used to improve District buildings and properties and/or to provide appropriate equipment.  On February 19, 2009, the Board of Trustees approved a Measure E Prioritization List that allocated funds to LCPA (Board item 13.03).  On August 19, 2010, the Board approved a Measure E base allocation of $740 per one time maximum ADA for high school age District resident students attending charter schools within the District for technology and equipment procurement; the approved total maximum distribution to LCPA is $301,920.00 (Board item 14.02).  In addition, the Board approved LCPA’s Technology Plan, and authorized distribution of $111,710.00 to proceed with the purchasing and implementation of that plan.  On September 19, 2013 the Board ratified an additional $96,827.99 of Measure E distribution for equipment for LCPA (Board item 8.06).
			 
To date, $275 million of the Measure E $349 million bond authorization has been issued (78.68%), making available additional funds for the District to purchase equipment on LCPA’s behalf.  The remaining balance can be approved for distribution.
			 
			 
Board Approved Measure E Base Allocation for LCPA
$301,920.00
Maximum current distribution, based on 78.68% Measure E bonds issued
$237,550.66
Previously authorized distribution
$208,537.99
Balance of funds available for additional equipment
$  29,012.67
			 
			 
LCPA serves 368 students.  They have identified a need for 105 graphic calculators, 12 base ranger systems, 12 docking stations, and 5 document cameras to support instruction, students and staff, and would like to use their remaining Measure E funds to remedy this equipment deficiency.  District staff support LCPA’s request, to the limit of available Measure E funding, based on providing equivalency of facilities standards for classrooms and typical furniture and equipment provisions for students and staff.  
			 
                                                                                                  
FISCAL IMPACT:
$29,012.67
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E bond funds
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve distribution of Measure E bond funds in an amount not to exceed $29,012.67, for provision of additional equipment for Latino College Preparatory Academy and Charter School.

REVIEWED BY:
Kelly Kwong, Senior Manager of Internal Controls
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action Regarding Capital Program Reorganization
		 
		 
On October 17th, the Board approved a Capital Program Reorganization (Board Item 14.01).  At that meeting, the Board requested a refined cost savings analysis that considered the three new staff positions that were added in the Facilities Department in fiscal years 2011-12 and 2012-13 (District Architect, Senior Project Manager, Project Manager).  The annual cost of those positions is $457,519 (salaries plus benefits).
		 
The reorganization is projected to realize cost savings in comparison to what the District currently pays to have these services performed by the Program Manager.  The cost savings calculation accounted for the cost of those three positions in both the current scenario and the proposed reorganized scenario; as such, the cost of those positions does not affect the cost savings calculation.  
		 
Staff expanded the cost analysis provided in Board Item 14.01 to include the total program management and District overhead costs from FY2010-11 through FY2014-15.  A summary is as follows:
